Chiron said: “By that virtue, which empowers my step To treat so wild a path, grant us, I pray, One of thy band, whom we may trust secure, Who to the ford may lead us, and convey Across, him mounted on his back.” Then on his right breast turning, Chiron thus To Nessus spake: �

“As ever on this side the boiling wave Thou seest diminishing,” the Centaur said. “So on the other, be thou well assur’d, It lower still and lower sinks its bed, Till in that part it reuniting join, Where ’t is the lot of tyranny to mourn.”

Noting the visages of some, who lay Beneath the pelting of that dolorous fire, One of them all I knew not. That pendent from his neck each bore a pouch With colours and with emblems various mark’d. "If our minds, when dreaming near the dawn, Are of the truth presageful, Shalt feel what Prato, (not to say the rest) Would fain might come upon thee" "For as time wears me, I shall grieve the more"

“When I was number’d with the dead, then came Saint Francis for me; but a cherub dark He met, who cried: “‘Wrong me not; he is mine, And must below to join the wretched crew, For the deceitful counsel which he gave.” Then, yielding to the forceful arguments, Of silence as more perilous

“What ails thee, Bocca? Ill knowest thou to flatter in this vale.” Then seizing on his hinder scalp, I cried: “Name thee, or not a hair shall tarry here” “Rend all away,” he answer’d, “yet for that I will not tell nor show thee

“Many,” exclaim’d the bard, “are these, who throng Around us: to petition thee they come.” Ne’er saw I fiery vapours with such speed Cut through the serene air at fall of night, Nor August’s clouds athwart the setting sun, That upward these did not in shorter space Return

Virgil describes a meeting with the Siren, who sang to him from the top of a mountain. He says he was so entranced by her voice that he followed her up the mountain. Virgil also describes how a dame of semblance holy appeared to him.

“I invest thee then With crown and mitre, sovereign o’er thyself. Expect no more Sanction of warning voice or sign from me, Free of thy own arbitrement to choose.”

‘I turn’d me full of wonder to my guide; And he did answer with a countenance Charg’D with no less amazement: whence my view Reverted to those lofty things, which came So slowly moving towards us, that the bride Would have outstript them on her bridal day’

“I am, in sooth, I am Beatrice. What! and hast thou deign’d at last Approach the mountain? knewest not, O man! Thy happiness is whole?” Down fell mine eyes On the clear fount, but there, myself espying, and sought the greensward: such a weight Of shame was on my forehead.

“I fain would know, if man By other works well done may so supply The failure of his vows, that in your scale They lack not weight.” I spake; and on me straight Beatrice look’d with eyes that shot forth sparks Of love celestial in such copious stream.

“If I have power to show one truth, soon that Shall face thee, which thy questioning declares Behind thee now conceal’d. Now make intelligent, clearing the doubt Thy speech hath raised in me; for much I muse, How bitter can spring up, when sweet is sown.”

The city's malady hath ever source In the confusion of its persons, as The body’s, in variety of food. I saw The Ughi, Catilini and Filippi, The Alberichi, Greci and Ormanni, Now in their wane, illustrious citizens.

“I was not held, I say, Long in expectance, when I saw the heav’n Wax more and more resplendent” “Behold,” Cried Beatrice, “the triumphal hosts Of Christ, and all the harvest reap’d at length Of thy ascending up these spheres.”

‘The track, our ventrous keel must furrow, brooks No unribb’d pinnace, no self-sparing pilot. But he, who thinks how ponderous the theme, And that ’t is lain upon a mortal shoulder, May pardon, if it tremble with the burden.’

“As a Hood Of frozen vapours streams adown the air, What time the she-goat with her skiey horn Touches the sun; so saw I there stream wide The vapours, who with us had linger’d late And with glad triumph deck th’ ethereal cope.”
“Pale January must be shor’d aside From winter’s calendar, these heav’nly spheres Shall roar so loud, that fortune shall be fain” “True fruit, Expected long, shall crown at last the bloom!”
“Breathe up in warbled melodies threefold Hosannas blending ever, from the three Transmitted. hierarchy of gods, for aye Rejoicing, dominations first, next then Virtues, and powers the third.”

The poem is about a group of bees who hover around a flower. The bees are 'like a troop of bees, Amid the vernal sweets alighting now, where their fragrant labour glows' The bees 'flew downward to the mighty flow’r'
